title: 104_hr2369
content:
The Act may be cited as the "Pacific Insular Areas Fisheries Empowerment Act of 1995" and references the Magnuson Fishery Conservation and Management Act. The Act includes findings, purposes, and policy statements. The Pacific Insular Areas of the United States are recognized for their unique historical, cultural, legal, political, and geographic circumstances, with a focus on the importance of fisheries resources for economic growth. The policy aims to ensure the exploration, exploitation, conservation, and management of fishery resources in the Pacific Insular Areas. The policy aims to ensure that resources in Pacific Insular Areas are explored, exploited, conserved, and managed for the benefit of the people in those areas. The term 'Pacific Insular Area' is defined as American Samoa, Guam, or the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands. Foreign fishing and international fishery agreements are addressed in the following section. The text discusses amendments to the authority for foreign fishing under a Pacific Insular Area Agreement, the authority to enter into such agreements, and the process for negotiating a Pacific Insular Area Fishery Agreement (PIAFA) upon the request of the Governor of a Pacific Insular Area. The text discusses the process for negotiating a Pacific Insular Area Fishery Agreement (PIAFA) to authorize foreign fishing within the exclusive economic zone adjacent to an Insular Area or for Continental Shelf fishery resources beyond that zone. It emphasizes the need for consultation with the Governor of the Insular Area and outlines the payment of fees to the Treasury of the Pacific Insular area by foreign fishing vessel owners. Foreign fishing under a PIAFA is not subject to certain sections of the law and shall be deposited in the treasury of the Insular Area for fishery conservation. The agreement must follow specific procedures and cannot be negotiated with countries violating international fishery agreements. SEC. 5. DOMESTIC FEES. Section 304 (16 U.S.C. 1854) is amended to allow the Secretary to enter into a cooperative agreement with the Governor of a Pacific Insular Area for the administration of a permit system and collection of fees for fisheries in the exclusive economic zone. The fees collected may be deposited into the treasury of the Pacific Insular Area for fishery conservation and management purposes. Regulations for fee levels can be established by the Secretary in concurrence with the Governor. The Secretary, in cooperation with the Governor of a Pacific Insular Area, can set fees for fisheries, ensuring they are reasonable and fair. The fees collected are not subject to certain regulations. SEC. 6. ENFORCEMENT.

Section 311 (16 U.S.C. 1861) is amended to include subsection (f) for enforcement in the Pacific Insular Areas, supporting cooperative agreements between Federal and Pacific authorities.

SEC. 7. CONFORMING AMENDMENT.

Section 307(2)(B) (16 U.S.C. 1857(2)(B)) and Section 311(g)(1) (16 U.S.C. 1861(g)(1)) are amended to include references to additional sections for conformity.
